baseline_groups.claim_summary: The basic conditional cash transfer (T1) increases monitored school attendance among eligible students in San Cristobal by approximately 3.2 percentage points.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3, Column 2. Coefficient 0.0316 (SE 0.0074, p<0.0001). N=5799, R2=0.089. OLS with baseline controls and school fixed effects, clustered at school level. Sample is SC survey-selected students in grades 6-10.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The savings-treatment conditional cash transfer (T2) increases monitored school attendance among eligible students in San Cristobal by approximately 2.7 percentage points.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3, Column 2. Coefficient 0.0270 (SE 0.0071, p=0.0002). Same model as G1 but reporting the T2_treat coefficient. Both T1 and T2 are included simultaneously in the regression.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The savings-treatment conditional cash transfer (T2) increases school enrollment among eligible students in San Cristobal by approximately 4.0 percentage points.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 4, Column 2. Coefficient 0.0396 (SE 0.0106, p=0.0002). N=8980, R2=0.172. OLS with baseline controls and school FE, clustered at school level. Sample is all SC students grades 6-10 (enrollment is administrative data, not requiring survey selection).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The basic conditional cash transfer (T1) has no statistically significant effect on school enrollment (in contrast to T2's significant positive effect).
baseline_groups.notes: Table 4, Column 2. Coefficient 0.0107 (SE 0.0102, p=0.296). Not significant at conventional levels. This null result for T1 on enrollment is itself a key finding: the savings treatment outperforms the basic treatment on the enrollment margin.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The tertiary/Suba treatment (T3) increases monitored school attendance among eligible students in Suba by approximately 5.6 percentage points.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3, Suba panel. Coefficient 0.0561 (SE 0.0199, p=0.005). N=930. Separate sample (Suba locality, grades 9-10 only). T3 is the tertiary savings treatment offered only in Suba.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The tertiary/Suba treatment (T3) has a marginally significant positive effect on enrollment in the Suba sample.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 4, Suba panel. Coefficient 0.0370 (SE 0.0196, p=0.059). N=1735. Marginally significant at 10% but not at 5%.

global_notes: Paper is Barrera-Osorio, Bertrand, Linden & Perez-Calle (2011) 'Improving the Design of Conditional Transfer Programs: Evidence from a Randomized Education Experiment in Colombia' (AEJ: Applied Economics). The study is an RCT in Bogota with three treatment arms: T1 (basic CCT with payments conditional on attendance), T2 (savings treatment with portion of transfer withheld for re-enrollment), and T3 (tertiary treatment offered in Suba locality only). Two main outcomes: monitored attendance (at_msamean, survey-selected students) and administrative enrollment (m_enrolled, all eligible students). Six baselines correspond to Tables 3-4 of the paper: T1 and T2 effects on attendance (G1, G2), T1 and T2 effects on enrollment (G3, G4), and T3 effects on attendance and enrollment in Suba (G5, G6). The G4 baseline is a documented null result (T1 has no enrollment effect). The specification search generates 89 total specifications across 10 categories. The winsorized attendance spec (funcform/winsorize_5_95/attendance_T1) is an exact duplicate of baseline_attendance_T1 because attendance is already bounded in [0,1] and winsorization at 5th/95th percentiles does not change any values. The z-score attendance spec (funcform/zscore/attendance_T1) has the same t-statistic and p-value as the baseline because z-scoring is a linear transformation.
